TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, frigid Typic Haplustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Campspass loam, ponderosa pine open timber (colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted).
Oi--2 inches to 0; layer of pine needles and leaves of shrubs and grass on a 1/2-inch thick layer of decomposed needles and twigs.
A--0 to 5 inches; very dark gray (10YR 3/1) loam, black (10YR 2/1) moist; weak medium platy structure parting to medium granules; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common medium and many very fine roots; common pores; coating and patches of light gray silt and fine sand grains; less than 1 percent red and yellow sandstone and slate fragments; slightly acid (pH 6.5); clear wavy boundary. (2 to 5 inches thick)
E--4 to 10 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) at bottom of peds to light gray (10YR 7/2) on tops of peds, loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; uncrushed, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, sticky and slightly plastic; common medium roots; common fine pores; thin continuous coating of clear silt and fine sand grains on peds; broken silt films on tops of peds; less than 1 percent red and yellow sandstone and slate fragments; slightly acid (pH 6.5); clear wavy boundary. (6 to 10 inches thick)
B/E--10 to 14 inches; B part (85 percent) brown (10YR 5/3) coated clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; E part (15 percent) light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) coated pale brown (10YR 6/3) moist, and grading with depth to yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) loam, weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; common medium roots; common fine pores; broken silt films on tops of peds and interfingering of silt film between peds; less than 1 percent red and yellow sandstone and slate fragments; neutral (pH 7.0); gradual boundary.  (4 to 10 inches thick)
Bt--14 to 25 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) clay loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, sticky and plastic; common medium roots; few fine pores; continuous distinct yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) clay films in pores extending out onto faces of peds; dark brown (10YR 3/2); few faint clay films on concave ped faces; less than 1 percent red and yellow sandstone and slate fragments; neutral (pH 7.0); many large krotovinas; abrupt wavy boundary.  (10 to 15 inches thick)
Bk--25 to 34 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) gravelly loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine blocky structure; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine matted roots; common fine pores; contains 25 percent porcelanite fragments 1/4-inch and less in diameter; common fine threads of lime; strongly effervescent; (pH 8.0); clear wavy boundary.  (9 to 20 inches thick)
2C--34 to 43 inches; yellowish red (5YR 4/6) silty clay loam, yellowish red (10YR 5/6) moist; firm, sticky and plastic; strongly effervescent; (pH 8.0); abrupt boundary.  (0 to 16 inches thick)
2R--43 to 60 inches; fractured slate, sandstone, and porcelanite.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Powder River County, Montana; SW 1/4 of sec. 23, T. 2 S., R. 46 E., on NE facing 35 percent slope under western yellow pine.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil temperature - 40 to 47 degrees F.
Moisture control section - approximately between the depths of 4 and 12 inches.
Depth to bedrock - 40 to 60 inches.
Depth to Bk horizon - 18 to 30 inches.
A horizon - Hue:  10YR or 2.5Y
Value:  3, 4, or 5 dry; 2 or 3 moist
Chroma:  1 or 2
Texture, less than 2 mm:  loam, fine sandy loam, or silt loam
Clay content:  15 to 27 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 10 percent channers
Reaction:  pH 6.1 to 7.8
E horizon - Hue:  10YR or 2.5Y
Value:  6 or 7 dry; 4 or 5 moist
Chroma:  2 or 3
Texture, less than 2 mm:  loam, fine sandy loam, or silt loam
Clay content:  15 to 20 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 10 percent channers or pebbles
Reaction:  pH 6.1 to 7.8
B/E horizon - Hue:  10YR or 2.5Y
Value:  B part 4 or 5, E part 6 or 7 dry; B part 3, 4, or 5, E part 4 or 5 moist
Chroma:  2, 3, or 4
Texture, less than 2 mm:  clay loam, silty clay loam, or clay
Clay content:  35 to 45 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 10 percent channers or pebbles
Reaction:  pH 6.6 to 7.8
Bt horizon - Hue:  10YR or 2.5Y
Value:  5, 6, or 7 dry; 4 or 5 moist
Chroma:  2, 3, or 4 moist
Texture, less than 2 mm:  clay loam, silty clay loam, or clay
Clay content:  35 to 45 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 10 percent channers or pebbles
Reaction:  pH 6.6 to 7.8
Bk horizon - Hue:  10YR or 2.5Y
Value:  6 or 7 dry; 4, 5, or 6 moist
Chroma:  3 or 4
Textures, less than 2 mm:  loam, silty clay loam, or clay loam
Clay content:  20 to 30 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 35 percent channers or pebbles
Calcium carbonate equivalent:  6 to 15 percent
Reaction:  pH 7.4 to 8.4
2C horizon - Hue:  10YR or 5YR
Value:  4, 5, or 6 dry; 4 or 5 moist
Chroma:  4 or 6
Textures, less than 2 mm:  loam, silty clay loam, or clay loam
Clay content:  25 to 35 percent clay
Rock fragments:  0 to 35 percent channers or pebbles
Reaction:  pH 7.4 to 8.4

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Citadel (SD), Fortwingate (NM), Goldvale (CO), Kelvin (ND), Larkson (CO), McVickers (AZ), Osoridge (NM), Pylon (MT), and Zuni (NM) series.  The Citadel soils do not have a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation and are mainly strongly acid above a depth of 23 inches.  The Fortwingate, Osoridge, and Pylon soils have lithic or paralithic bedrock at moderate depths.  The Fortwingate and Osoridge soils do not have a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation.  Also, the Pylon soils have a very hard or hard and massive surface, and an extremely hard argillic horizon.  The Goldvale and Larkson soils do not have a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation.  Kelvin soils do not have a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation, or a thin dark A horizon.  The McVickers soils have the base of the argillic horizon at a depth of 40 inches or deeper, and do not have a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation.  The Zuni soils formed in materials weathered from coarse grained granite and are free of carbonate throughout the soil.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Campspass soils are on hill slopes, fan terraces, and benches.  They formed in colluvium and materials derived from consolidated sedimentary rocks.  Elevations are 3,500 to 4,500 feet.  Slopes are 3 to 75 percent.  These soils formed in colluvium and materials derived from semiconsolidated sedimentary rock.  The climate is characterized by long, cold winters; moist springs; and early, warm summers.  Mean annual precipitation is 15 to 19 inches.  Mean annual temperature is 38 to 45 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 90 to 110 days.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Campspass soils are used mainly for native range, wildlife habitat, watershed, and for timber production.  Potential native vegetation is mainly ponderosa pine, chokecherry, dogwood, hawthorne, serviceberry, Oregon-grape, and pinegrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Campspass soils are moderately extensive and occur in small areas in southeastern Montana and in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Powder River County (Powder River Area), Montana, 1967.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Soil Interpretations Records:  MT0440 and MT1035.  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this soil are:
a. ochric epipedon from the surface to 10 inches (A and E horizons); an albic horizon from 4 to 10 inches (E horizon); and argillic horizon from 10 to 25 inches (B/E and Bt horizons); a horizon of secondary carbonate accumulation (Bk horizon); an R horizon at 43 inches.  The particle size control section is the upper 20 inches of the argillic horizon.  Campspass soils have a frigid temperature regime and an ustic moisture regime.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
